diff_hunk:
@@ -122,4 +122,19 @@ def git_piston(path)
     stdout = cmd("cd #{full_path.inspect} && git pull && git push 2>&1")
     @logger.info "Fired git piston on #{full_path.inspect}.  STDOUT:\n\n#{stdout}"
   end
+
+  # [Rsync] Simple sync of two files/folders using rsync.
+  # 
+  # If you set the delete variable to true, it will remove files from the 'to' location to keep the folders in sync.
+  #
+  #   sync('~/music', '/backup/music')
+  def sync(from, to, delete=false)
body:
To make future expansion easier (and improve readability a bit), could we change the usage from:

``` ruby
sync('~/foo', '~/bar', true)
```

To this instead?

``` ruby
sync('~/foo', '~/bar', delete: true) # or :delete => true in 1.8
```

diff_hunk:
@@ -122,4 +122,19 @@ def git_piston(path)
     stdout = cmd("cd #{full_path.inspect} && git pull && git push 2>&1")
     @logger.info "Fired git piston on #{full_path.inspect}.  STDOUT:\n\n#{stdout}"
   end
+
+  # [Rsync] Simple sync of two files/folders using rsync.
+  # 
+  # If you set the delete variable to true, it will remove files from the 'to' location to keep the folders in sync.
+  #
+  #   sync('~/music', '/backup/music')
+  def sync(from, to, delete=false)
+    # expand path removes trailing slash
+    # cannot use str[-1] due to ruby 1.8.7 restriction
+    from = File.expand_path(from) + (from.end_with?('/') ? '/' : '')
+    to = File.expand_path(to) + (to.end_with?('/') ? '/' : '')
+    delete_option = delete ? '--delete ' : ''
+    stdout = cmd("rsync -au #{delete_option}#{from.inspect} #{to.inspect} 2>&1")
body:
This will make changes to the file system even if `noop` is set.  (You'll notice that's an issue in `git_piston` as well, but that's being deprecated per #18.)

If `sync` is a feature that we intend to keep around, it should respect `@file_options[:noop]` and not actually run the command in that case.  It might make sense to take care of that check in `cmd`, actually.  Up to you.

@@ -123,5 +123,37 @@ module Maid

       end

+        @to      = '~/Reference'

+

+        @maid.should_receive(:cmd).with(%Q{rsync -a -u "#@home/Downloads/" "#@home/Reference" 2>&1})
+        @maid.sync(@from, @to)
+      end
+
+      it 'should log the action' do
+        @logger.should_receive(:info)
+        @maid.sync(@from, @to)

diff_hunk:
@@ -44,6 +44,24 @@ def trash(path)
     end
   end
 
+
+
+  # Remove directory/file
+  #
+  # Directory/file is removed securely (See FileUtils.remove_entry_secure for further details).
+  # 
+  # Options:
+  # - :force => boolean
+  #
+  # remove('~/Downloads/foo.zip')
+  def remove(path, options = {})
+    path = File.expand_path(path)
+    options = {:secure => true}.merge(@file_options).merge(options)
body:
Just curious:  why is `:secure => true` the default?

Being able to do a secure delete is useful, but I would imagine for most people, it's the 20% case rather than the 80% case.  Could we change it to `false` and make it an option instead?

body:
I can empathize with that.  But in this case I'm just thinking "huh, a spec that does `rm -rf`... seems like it could be dangerous".  :smile:

Really, I'd like to start using [`FakeFS`](https://github.com/defunkt/fakefs) for testing and forget about stubbing all these specific methods.  That's a longer term goal, but if you'd ever like to take a look at doing that, by all means.  All your involvement is very appreciated.

diff_hunk:
@@ -175,12 +175,27 @@ def disk_usage(path)
     end
   end
 
+  # In Unix speak, "ctime".
+  #
+  #   created_at('foo.zip') # => Sat Apr 09 10:50:01 -0400 2011
+  def created_at(path)
+    File.ctime(File.expand_path(path))
+  end
+
   # In Unix speak, "atime".
   #
-  #   last_accessed('foo.zip') # => Sat Apr 09 10:50:01 -0400 2011
-  def last_accessed(path)
+  #   accessed_at('foo.zip') # => Sat Apr 09 10:50:01 -0400 2011
+  def accessed_at(path)
     File.atime(File.expand_path(path))
   end
+  alias :last_accessed :accessed_at # keep for legacy compatibility.
body:
I swear I've seen a library that lets you do something like this:

``` ruby
deprecate :last_accessed, :accessed_at
```

That makes it show a nice deprecation notice, aliases, etc.  Or maybe just part of that...  At any rate, let's try to give a notice so we can get rid of the older name later (version 0.2.0 or above).

diff_hunk:
@@ -175,13 +175,35 @@ def disk_usage(path)
     end
   end
 
+  # In Unix speak, "ctime".
+  #
+  #   created_at('foo.zip') # => Sat Apr 09 10:50:01 -0400 2011
+  def created_at(path)
+    File.ctime(File.expand_path(path))
+  end
+
   # In Unix speak, "atime".
   #
-  #   last_accessed('foo.zip') # => Sat Apr 09 10:50:01 -0400 2011
-  def last_accessed(path)
+  #   accessed_at('foo.zip') # => Sat Apr 09 10:50:01 -0400 2011
+  def accessed_at(path)
     File.atime(File.expand_path(path))
   end
 
+  # In Unix speak, "atime". kept for backwards compatibility.
+  #
+  #   accessed_at('foo.zip') # => Sat Apr 09 10:50:01 -0400 2011
+  def last_accessed(path)
+    @logger.warning "last_accessed has been replaced by accessed_at."
body:
@phoolish  I'm thinking the deprecation notice should go to STDERR instead, just so it's more noticeable to users.  (That way it would go to the cron mail or show up in front of the user if they're invoking `maid clean` directly.  People probably won't notice it as easily in the log.)

I'm pretty sure that `warn` does that...

``` ruby
warn '[DEPRECATION] last_accessed has been replaced by accessed_at.'
```

How does that sound?

**Edit:** The deprecation library I'm thinking of might be a part of Rails... or this one seems similar enough:  https://rubygems.org/gems/deprecated

body: I was thinking that as well, but if we did that we would want a separate class just for logger to handle any options passed by the user.  This way they have the best of both worlds.  Either they define a logger or we do.  Plus, it deals with all the testing issues.

@@ -419,4 +471,15 @@ def expand(path)

     Array(paths).map { |path| expand(path) }
   end
+
+  def mdls_to_array(path, attribute)
+    return [] unless os_x?
+    raw = cmd("mdls -raw -name #{attribute} #{ path }")
+    clean = raw[1, raw.length - 2]
+    clean.split(/,\s+/).map { |s| t = s.strip; t[1, t.length - 2] }
+  end
+
+  def os_x?
+    !cmd("which mdls").empty?
body:
Regarding:

> To be able to make it "just work" maid is going to need to be aware if it's running on OS X. Any thoughts on how you would prefer to do that detection (or if you don't want to do that)?

This seems to be duplicating [`Maid::Platform.osx?`](https://github.com/benjaminoakes/maid/blob/master/lib/maid/platform.rb#L13).

diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
-class Maid::Rule < Struct.new(:description, :instructions)
+class Maid::Rule < Struct.new(:description, :instructions, :maid)
body: @benjaminoakes Or should I remove this maid instance variable and add an additional parameter to the follow method?
This should probably share code with `downloading?` in some way.
@benjaminoakes Yes, it should. But I can't find a proper way to do so. The `ignore` option can only take paths or regular expressions while `downloading?` is more complexed. Any suggestions?

It seems like we need to refactor to enable this.  Moving the regexps to some kind of data structure would probably involved.

For example:

``` ruby
def downloading?(path)
  downloading_file_regexps.any? { |re| path.match(re) }
end

private

def downloading_file_regexps
  [/\.crdownload$/, /\.download$/, /\.aria2$/, /\.td$/, /\.td.cfg$/, /\.part$/]
end
```

That doesn't quite capture all of it, but it's close.

Hrm... this could have problems if people are using `rvm` or something else that changes the executable path on occasion... (e.g. Ruby upgrades)

That said, I don't know a better approach off the top of my head.
